results.title: Le Pactole = the Loot
results.brief_description:
A young couple pulls off a bank robbery only to be blackmailed by a witness, who turns out to be a corrupt police officer.

Credits: Producer, Roger Fleytoux ; director, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; writers, Patrick Granier, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; photography, Edmond Richard ; music, Roger Loubet.
Cast: Richard Bohringer, Patrick Sebastien, Pauline Lafont, Marie Laforet, Bernadette Lafont.

results.title: Le Nozze di Figaro: opera comica in quattro atti
results.creator_credit: Osterreichischer Rundfunk-Fernsehen, Plaza Media, Mediascope and Peter Sellars
results.brief_description: A comic opera in four acts, music by Mozart and libretto by Lorenzo Da Ponte. This performance, directed by Peter Sellars, is set in modern times, in Trump Tower, Manhattan, 52 floors above Fifth Avenue. The action takes place in a single day, where love, fidelity and loyalty are all put to the test. Features singers Sanford Sylvan (Figaro), Jeanne Ommerle (Susanna), James Maddalena (Count Almaviva), Jayne West (Countess Almaviva), Susan Larson (Cherubino), Lynn Torgove (Barbarina), Frank Kelley (Don Basilio), David Evitts (Doctor Bartolo), Sue Ellen Kuzma (Marcellina), Herman Hildebrand (Antonio), William Cotton (Don Curzio), and the Arnold-Schonberg-Chor. Also features the Wiener Symphoniker conducted by Craig Smith. This co-production was originally staged for the Pepsico Summerfare Festival, The International Performing Arts Festival of the State University of New York at Purchase, by director Christopher Hunt. Sung in Italian, no English subtitles.

results.title: Le Mur = the Wall
results.brief_description:
Three prisoners await execution by firing squad after their capture during the Spanish Civil War. Pablo is a loyalist jailed after he searched for his brother. An Irish mercenary and a Belgian physician are his cellmates. Flashbacks recall their lives before the war as they spend their last moments waiting for their date with death.

Credits: Producer, Claude Jaeger ; director, Serge Roullet ; writers, Jean-Paul Sartre, Serge Roullet ; photography, Denys Clerval ; music, Edgardo Canton ; assistant director, Benoit Jacquot.
Cast: Michel del castillo, Denis Maharrey, Matthieu Klossowski, Bernard Anglade, Rene Darmon, Jorge Lavelli, Peter Kassovitz.

results.title: Le Misanthrope (TV Version)
results.brief_description:
Alceste, disgusted with the hypocrisy of the world, has declared that there is no good in man and has vowed never to lie about the virtues of others. He is, of course, the misanthrope of the title. This attitude gets him into a considerable amount of trouble, including a law suit which he loses because he refuses to flatter the judge. Alceste is in love with the flirtatious and shallow Cime. So much so that is is incaplable of noticing in her the defaults he so despises in other people.

Credits: Director, Jacques-Gerard Cornu ; photography, Jean-Jacques Graude ; art direction, Willy Holt.
Cast: Jacques Dumesnil, Anouk Ferjac, Giselle Touret, Bernard Dheran, Jacques Charon.

results.title: Le Miroir a Deux Faces = the Mirror Has Two Faces
results.brief_description:
A rather unambitious schoolmaster, living with his mother, marries a very plain woman. After six dreary years of marriage, the wife is transformed into a beauty by plastic surgery only to see her husband’s indifference turn into jealousy.

Credits: Producer, Alain Poire ; director, Andre Cayatte ; writers, Andre Cayatte, Gerard Oury, Denis Perret, Jean Meckert ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Louiguy.
Cast: Michele Morgan, Bourvil, Ivan Desny, Elisabeth Manet, Sandra Milo, Sylvie, Jane Marken, Carette.

results.title: Le Miracle des Loups = the Miracle of the Wolves
results.brief_description:
Robert Cottereau, standard bearer of Charles, duke of Burgundy, is in love with Jeanne Fouquet, god-daughter of King Louis XI. During a ball given by Charles, Lord Chateauneuf, a member of Louis XI’s party, tries to rape Jeanne. This causes a rupture between the King and the Duke and a war between France and Burgundy. Robert and Jeanne are separated. When Jeanne, carrying a secret letter from the King to Burgundy, is pursued by Chateauneuf, she benefits from the protection of a pack of wolves. This story was originally filmed by Raymond Bernard in 1924.

Credits: Producers, Paul Cadeac, Rene Bezard ; director, Andre Hunebelle ; writers, Jean Halain, Pierre Foucaud, Andre Hunebelle ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Jean Marion.
Cast: Jean Marais, Rossana Schiaffino, Roger Hanin, Jean-Louis Barrault, Louis Arbessier.

results.title: Le Million
results.brief_description:
“The plot of ‘Le million’ comes straight out of the great tradition of silent film comedy: a winning lottery ticket left in a tattered coat gives rise to a series of cinematic chases and comic misunderstandings. The story, adapted from a stage farce, is told in operetta form, but with a very modern Brechtian twist. This apect of the film probably grew out of the director’s German contacts. (…) In ‘Le million’, a clearly Brechtian master criminal named Pere La Tulipe has a band of henchmen who sing about the joys of living outside the law. A basic promise of the plot, that a good friend will sell out his comrade for enough money, also has Brechtian resonances. The film’s detached, boisterously satiric tone, much of which shows a decidely leftist bent in its use of class stereotypes, is quite unlike the straighforward populist sentimentality of ‘Sous les toits de Paris’”. Reference: Alan Williams. ‘Republic of images: a history of French filmmaking’. Harvard University Press, 1992. See also: ‘100% parlant et chantant 1930-1933’ [X000650] for an overview of Rene Clair’s work in the 1930s.

Credits: Producer, Frank Clifford ; director, Rene Clair ; writer, Rene Clair ; photography, Georges Perinal ; music, Armand Bernard, Philippe Pars, Georges van Parys ; assistant director, Georges Lacombe ; art direction, Lazare Meerson.
Cast: Annabella, Rene Lefevre, Paul Ollivier, Vanda Greville, Odette Talazac, Raymond Cordy.

results.title: Le Meme bateau
results.brief_description: A summary of the work UNICEF is doing to give all children an equal chance in life. Using animated cut-out cartoon style, this charming but pointed allegory tells the story of four children in the same boat. Two from rich countries have shiny oars to row their boat through life’s waters, while the two from poorer countries have only broken oars

results.title: Le Marriage de Vidocq = Vidocq's Wedding
results.brief_description:
Vidocq and Annette would like to get married. They pay a visit to Jacquelin in order to chose a wedding ring. Caught in a random police raid, the pair narrowly escapes. Annette goes her own way while Vidocq seeks refuge with the ‘other’ Mrs. Vidocq.

Credits: Producer, Etienne Laroche ; director, Marcel Bluwal ; writer, Georges Neveux ; photography, Maurice Damien ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernard Noel, Alain Mottet, Genevieve Fontanel, Stephane Ariel, Eugene Berthier, Teddy Bilis, Christian Brocard, Leonce Corne, Jacques Monot, Henri Virlojeux.

results.title: Le mariage de Figaro ou la folle journee = The marriage of Figaro
results.brief_description:
“This is detestable, it will never be played!” was the cry that rang out of the halls of French King Louis XVI when he read the script for a new play by Pierre-Augustin Caron de Beaumarchais (1732-1799), ‘La folle journee, ou Le mariage de Figaro’. The King felt that Figaro was impudent and disrespectful as a lower-class citizen because of the way he treats his superiors in the play. According to Louis XVI, the foundations of European social structure would be in jeopardy should this play be allowed to be produced - the truth of the matter was that private shows were going on all over Paris. The King finally acquiesced and the play was given publicly on April 27, 1784 - but not without a fair share of cuts and subtractions. Consequently, the play was a huge success, and was soon translated into German. On January 31st, 1785, Joseph II of Austria gave a memorandum prohibiting a German version from appearing in Vienna. It was not long after this edict was given that Mozart suggested to da Ponte that they use it as a subject for his new Italian opera. ‘Le mariage de Figaro’ (actually finished in 1778) is one of three in a set of plays written by Beaumarchais. Reference: http://www.artswire.org/~mrd/nozze/1784.beaumarchais.html

Credits: Producer, Pierre Guerin ; director, Jean Meyer ; photography, Henri Alekan ; music, W. A. Mozart ; technical adviser, Michel Deville.
Cast: Jean Meyer, Louis Seigner, Georges Chamarat, Jean Piat, Georges Descrieres.
